item.description:
On October 12, 1692, the Colony of Massachusetts put an end to the Salem Witch Trials. The Governor of Massachusetts decided that spectral evidence--evidence from the supernatural--could no longer be admissible in court. October 12th has become a day to renew our resolve to resist supernaturalism, and to celebrate our communities of reason. For more information, please visit http://secularseasons... and http://freethoughtday....

As part of our 2010 Freethought Day activities, we'll be gathering for dinner in Salem, Mass. All are welcome, but please do not RSVP "yes" unless you are sure you plan to attend.

Please use the mailing list or the comments thread on this event page to coordinate carpooling. Members who wish to take public transportion will see that the Newburyport/Rockport line has a commuter rail stop in Salem, just a few blocks from the downtown area. The last inbound train departs Salem at 10:38, and rolls into North Station at 11:07, leaving you in good position to catch the Green, Blue, Orange or Red line to your destination.
item.name: Freethought Day Program: Dinner in Salem
